Articles.Content:
EXTRASOLAR

License: Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike

 

DESCRIPTION:

The Extrasolar mod adds the red dwarf star "Valentine" in orbit around Kerbol. Orbiting Valentine are several new planets and moons to discover. Because Valentine is so far away, you will probably have to download some mods in order to make the trip easier. DO NOT INSTALL THIS FROM CKAN!

LIST OF CELESTIAL BODIES:

Spoiler
  • Valentine
    • Heba
      • Serex
    • Solyth
    • Fust
      • Kuprus
    • Mir
    • Lomina
      • Maol
      • Javine
      • Ucella
      • Deemo
      • Pael

SCREENSHOTS:

 

DOWNLOAD ON SPACEDOCK

Edited February 19, 2020 by AndrewDraws
Giving this a try with EVE+AVP+Scatterer.

Extrasolar has yet to become compatible with AVP as well as Spectra, but I will be working on compatibility. It should be a matter of just a handful of config files. Extrasolar is compatible with SVE however.
wow, i wasn't expecting extrasolar to get updated again! i gotta check this new version out now!

Good to know. I'm still flying around in the atmosphere for this save, and my clouds are still there.

So it didn't break anything I can see, which is all I care about for now. It will be a while before I get there.

Does it play nice with Research Bodies?

Yay it's back!

Any recommended mods for getting to Valentine?

8 hours ago, Grigetio said:

Good to know. I'm still flying around in the atmosphere for this save, and my clouds are still there.

So it didn't break anything I can see, which is all I care about for now. It will be a while before I get there.

Does it play nice with Research Bodies?

Extrasolar should work with research bodies, but I haven't created fancy descriptions for when you discover something

17 minutes ago, Space Nerd said:

Yay it's back!

Any recommended mods for getting to Valentine?

If you want something that is extremely complicated and challenging, then KSPIE is the way to go. Otherwise, Near Future Propulsion and Photon Sailor are both good options.
This makes me unspeakably happy!

3 hours ago, Space Nerd said:

Yay it's back!

Any recommended mods for getting to Valentine?

I recommend FFT

https://github.com/ChrisAdderley/FarFutureTechnologies

Nerteas (semi-hidden) counterpart to KSPI
So this pack no longer has any dependencies? Specifically kopernicus? vOv

56 minutes ago, Stone Blue said:

So this pack no longer has any dependencies? Specifically kopernicus? vOv

Like any other planet pack, this requires kopernicus
wait i've always thought lomina was more the mass of uranus or neptune why is it 5 times the mass of jool (jool is around 4e+24 kg and lomina is about 2e+25 kg)? has it always been like that??

1 hour ago, electricpants said:

wait i've always thought lomina was more the mass of uranus or neptune why is it 5 times the mass of jool (jool is around 4e+24 kg and lomina is about 2e+25 kg)? has it always been like that??

Lomina has always been like that. Lomina is basically if Neptune was the size of jupiter. Because Ice Giants are more dense, it means Lomina has a much greater mass than Jool despite having only a marginally larger radius.

Edited October 11, 2019 by AndrewDraws

9 minutes ago, AndrewDraws said:

Lomina has always been like that. Lomina is basically if Neptune was the size of Jupiter. Because Ice Giants are more dense, it means Lomina has a much greater mass than Jool despite having only a marginally larger radius.

wow, i've used extrasolar since javine was a water world and i guess i never noticed lomina was that big ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Edited October 11, 2019 by electricpants

On 10/9/2019 at 12:44 PM, AndrewDraws said:

If you want something that is extremely complicated and challenging, then KSPIE is the way to go. Otherwise, Near Future Propulsion and Photon Sailor are both good options.

Extremely complicated? you only need a Deadalus Engine, a reactor and a few radiators and your good to go.

9 minutes ago, FreeThinker said:

Extremely complicated? you only need a Deadalus Engine, a reactor and a few radiators and your good to go.

I mean, it isn't too complicated for me, but I find that quite a few people tend to get confused and overwhelmed by KSPIE

Edited October 11, 2019 by AndrewDraws

Glad to see this back. Did Valentine's orbit change? It looks a lot more elliptical. I might need to move it in my install (I am using JNSQ) since the periapsis is so close to the outer planets in JNSQ.

6 minutes ago, panarchist said:

Glad to see this back. Did Valentine's orbit change? It looks a lot more elliptical. I might need to move it in my install (I am using JNSQ) since the periapsis is so close to the outer planets in JNSQ.

Valentine's orbit did indeed change to reflect a slightly more realistic binary star orbit (most binary stars orbit each other rather elliptically). I'm assuming the reason why Valentine's periapsis is so close to the outer planets in JNSQ is because JNSQ is scaled up quite a bit but Extrasolar is not. However, I will create compatibility with JNSQ in the future.

5 hours ago, FreeThinker said:

Extremely complicated? 

I'd say, rather complex compared to the simpler stock-mechanics.
I would definitely not say that most of KSPIE is "plug and play"

5 hours ago, AndrewDraws said:

Valentine's orbit did indeed change to reflect a slightly more realistic binary star orbit (most binary stars orbit each other rather elliptically). I'm assuming the reason why Valentine's periapsis is so close to the outer planets in JNSQ is because JNSQ is scaled up quite a bit but Extrasolar is not. However, I will create compatibility with JNSQ in the future.

Also, the Argument of Periapsis on both systems is such that the apoapsis of JNSQ is really close to the periapsis of Extrasolar. I look forward to the eventual compatibility patch but for now I'll just use it in my "stock Kerbin" install. I used to have Extrasolar set up along with Outer Planets Mod and Other Worlds all in the same instance (and once with GPP Secondary) - honestly, I love that so many Kopernicus-reliant mods can work so well together. Plus every release you've done of this mod has greatly improved it - it's always great to see the progression, and always a new exploration opportunity.

Here's a random from the surface of Maol. Also, I will be updating Extrasolar again soon. Changes will include some minor tweaks here and there, as well as compatibility with AVP and Spectra

Edited October 27, 2019 by AndrewDraws
Its awesome to see this back, will need to get some Kerbal's feet on the ground in 100 years.
One thing I LOVED about this was the feeling of absolute discovery when I landed on those planets for the first time, the sheer wonder at seeing strange new landscapes
Extrasolar has been updated once again! Enjoy

Wow I was devastated when I saw this was taken down. Now I'm glad it is back!
